Thank you for being with us today.
Hello, thank you, Councilmembers for having me here today to present to you Mayor Harrell's nominee for director of Seattle's office of housing, Maiko Winkler-Chin.

As you on the Council's housing and Finance Committee know, access to housing is a major component to solving some of the city and region's biggest challenges including transportation, Homeilousness, displacement and climate change.
The creation and preservation of affordable housing has never been more central to the people of Seattle which is why Mayor Harrell nominated Winkler-Chin to serve as the next director.
Her stellar reputation precedes her, having served 7 years at the China town Seattle district PDA and as a former member of the housing oversight board.

Before the nomination was referred to you, we consulted with stake holders including two former housing directors, the chair of the Seattle housing authority board, and representatives from the housing development Consource M, the urban League of metropolitan Seattle, and several employees at the office of housing.

The clear conclusion about Maiko Winkler-Chin which you heard through public testimony is she is a proven and compassionate person with deep roots in The- diverse communities, an experienced housing provider that understands the Dynamices for providing housing in the unique Dynamics of Sealt, and someone who has the intention of leading the city through the 2022 renewal proposal.
Councilmembers, I can't think of someone better to lead the office of housing at a time when new housing has never been more essential.
I thank you for your consideration of her nomination.
We have big challenges ahead but with Maiko at the helm, those challenges present nothing but opportunities.
Before I turn it over to her for her opening remarks, Maiko, it has been a pleasure to work with you over the last few months and we appreciate the Exies you bring and the passion you bring.
We have a lot of work to do.
Thank you very much, deputy Mayor Washington.
Deputy Winkler-Chip, these are incredible remarks for someone who has already had an incredible career and Trujethory.
We are excited to have you talk about what interest Td you in the role.
I want to thank my colleagues who contributed to Dwhegz you received.
Thank you to Aaron house on my staff who helped compile the questions.
And for you for filling out all of the important issue areas.

As you can tell from the depth of the questions you received, there is great interest from the committee and community who helped to contribute some of the questions around how we address the crisis of housing with urgency and really use the community lens, community driven analysis for how quickly and effectively, we can bring additional housing Online.

And not just housing but as office of housing has shown in the past, when we partner with community partners like you, when you are on the other side of the walls, we can create a sense of place and belonging and community through the housing that we build if we do housing coupled with plazas and community space, and other amenities like small businesses and child care centers.

Really excited about the work you have din at the Seattle China town International district preservation authority where you served as the housing manager, where you served as the executive director, and for the work you have done in the community, working to bring together affordable housing Advths with folks who are interested in using new real estate, older buildings, to create a sense of community and place.
And also, very excited about the work you have done to sit on task forces and advisory committees are ready within the city, and the role you played in shaping public policy in our city.
To have your expertise in community and to have that lens carried into the role couldn't be more of an incredible NOTE among many high profile accomplishments on your resume already.
So with the policy that you put on the community driven approach, welcome and please tell us more about what interests you in this role.
Thank you Councilmember for that kind introduction.
Thank you to all of the community members.
You are going to make me ugly cry.
For those who know, let's not get reflective because I get a little too emotional.
First, I'm shocked, honored, and humbled to be with you here today.
I would never imagined being in this position.
I want to thank Mayor Harrell for asking.
I hope he doesn't regret it.
I know that you all have my resume and have seen the paper version of me.
Some of you have worked with me in the past.
I thought it would be good for you to know a little bit of why I'm coming to this job and what I bring to it.
As I was reflecting and I don't want to reflect too much because I get a little too emotional sometimes.
At the heart of it, I think if you take care of community, community takes care of you.
My mother and I when we moved to the United States when I was 5, she was 46.
We moved from Japan.
My father was in the military.
He was retired by the time I was born.
When we moved to America, my mom and I didn't speak English.
We were pretty lost.
We relied on our community to get us through.
For my mom, that community was the people who were from the island of Alkideo in Japan which is remote.
They speak a Funky dialect of Japanese, not the pretty Tokyo Japanese.
They helped her get jobs as a dish washer, as a restaurant cook, as a House keeper.
They made sure that I tried to stay on track because I tended to wander.
They wanted to make sure I graduated from high school and all of that.
They helped us both understand--they helped us understand the cultural context in which we were in.
In my community, the teachers, kids that grew up in the neighborhood, that sort of thing.
They really helped explain America to us, like weird things of what the Prom was, why I should learn how to drive, and ensured that I had the opportunity to attend college.
Because my mother had different ideas and didn't think I should do that.
It was because community was so important and the value I placed on community has shaped how I looked at the path of my work.
To be clear, you have heard a lot from the affordable housing community.
You have heard some people talk about community development.
I am not on affordable housing developer.
I'm kind of related to them.
As people who have known me, I will say I'm that Cousin in community development.
Because we are somehow related.
I use some of the same tools they do but I come at it from a different orientation.
Some of the housing things that have fallen into the work I have done is asset management, property operations, and some level of development.
I also wanted to work for community and I'm lucky to do so both in the Rainier Valley and in the China town Id.
The China town Id I will say is a very good teacher.
You learn a lot of things while you are working in that community.
I had great mentors and support around me that helped show me what the work needs to be and how we get work done.
I had often thought that maybe I would end up working in the city.
As a daughter of an immigrant, working for the city seemed safe and stable and that was my mom's dream.
But I never thought I would be the director of a department.
So if confirmed, I have the privilege of being at this job in the specific time where the need for housing is great as you have said.
Homelessness and public safety are the biggest concerns of city residents.
Our staff and partners, especially those who work on the ground have been through very trying times.
If confirmed, I look forward to working with you as I have with some of you for quite a while now.
I think you have heard from some people that said I'm pretty authentic.
I think that's a nice way of saying whatever it is they are saying.
And honestly, as Joel Ing referred to, I don't think I could change who I am at my core, even if I tried.
I do like to learn new things but the inside of me is pretty well locked in.
I want to thank you for the confirmation questions.
I appreciated the time thinking through the questions.
Since I Transitioned to this new place known as the city, it is so different than China town.
It has been a good experience to go through the questions.
I think it is time to start the conversation.
Thank you very much.

Also served as a member of the community development transportation and planning advisory committees as well as other national and local boards such as the national coalition of Asian Americans.
I want to also NOTE Asian American Pacific Islander development and Seattle based crescent collaboration.

As rosy mentioned at the Beginnin of the presentation, one of the ways we are advancing equity in the office of housing is through the home ownership initiatives.
Seattle's Rainier Valley is one of the most Culturaly and economically diverse neighborhoods.
It is facing significant displacement pressures.
The goal of the Rainier Valley home ownership initiative is to create at least 100 permanently affordable homes for first time home buyers to prevent displacement of current residents.

This is being done through the acquisition of surplus property on the light rail used for construction staging purposes and was transferred to the city at no cost to develop permanently affordable home Onership.
As part of this program, we are building capacities for community based organizations to participate in development and Longterm stewardship of the land.

The Office of housing and sound transit worked with Puget sound Sage and other community based organizations to conduct community engagement, targeting Bipoc communities who live or have connections to the Rainier Valley to better understand priorities for the sites.
Next slide?
And so in addition to the initiatives we have spoken about, we have the opportunity to respond to Covid-19 with emergency rental assistance for funding from the U.S. Department of Treasury.
Between July of 2021 and March of 2022, we Havestributed $30 million to over 7,000 households.
In order to do this, we partnered with United way of King County and numerous other community based organizations.
The Cdo's we are Partnerring with largely Bipoc led and serving Bipoc communities.
This was an intentional decision with a goal of director resources to Bipoc communities because they are most impacted by Covid, the pandemic, and historically racist policies.
The majority of the heads of households that we serve through emergency rental assistance program identify as people of color.
34% identify as white.

To put this in comparison to overall Seattle demographics, according to the most recent data available from the 2014-2018 community survey, Seattle's general population is 62% white and 38% Bipoc and Hispanic.
We are meeting our equity goals by serving more households of color compared to the general population.
And then the folks that we are serving through the program also are largely people with low or extremely low incomes.
Our largest demographic is less than 30% of A.M.I ..

Along side the Covid-19 rental assistance program policy and programs, I'm here to talk about two other policies and programs we have for notice of attempt to sale and clean program.
The notice of attempt is a notice to sell recurring affordable housing to the city.
The city and partnership with community partners can use the notification information to evaluate properties and deploy a range of property preservation tools including incentive and acquisition.
This can help residents seek tenant protections and relocation resources if necessary.
Currently, O.H.
Is in the process of revealing the program with the goal to make it more accessible and equitable and responsive to community needs.
Secondly, the clean deep program is a relatively new addition to the direct assistance program along side Weatheration programs.
Oil to electric program also known as the clean heat program is a free program focused on creating oil heated homes to electric heat source.
This helps reduce energy costs and helps the city achieve carbon reduction goals.
O.H.
Has completed 56O.T.E .'s conversions in single family residences.

We leverage Seattle funds after the conversion.
Out reach and engagement is focused on environmental justice in the Bipoc communities of beacon heel and Rainier valley.
Recently, the program received an extension of the program beginning in 2022.
The goal is to convert 125 single family homes each year.

Continuing on with the policy and programs that are focused on equity, I wanted to highlight our community preference policy which has been in effect for the past year or so.
The community preference policy allows developers with high risk of displacement neighborhoods to set aside specific units for specific preferences.
The preference times Whee identified are folks who previously lived in the neighborhood, folks who currently live in the neighborhood or folks who utilize or have community ties to the neighborhood.
This preference policy came out from community.

It was an ask from community members and advocates to have a right to return policy to try to fight displacement and to bring folks who were displaced or previously lived in the neighborhood back to the places.
To date, we have had two rental projects fall through implement preference.
We have garner House near the Mount Baker link station.
And Jackson heights is in the central district.
Theyiment Mrmented 50% of community preference, did thorough Afirmative marketing and both were effective and hit 50% goal.
The stories of those who lived in the central district and moved out to Kink County and came back to live in Jackson heights.
We are looking forward to continuing the policy as it applies to home rental policies.

We are using the funds to scale up operations or to reach and serve more community members.
We have an examine here of services of life style.

We are also working with the central area collaborative.

We are also Partnerring with living and providing for communities for in home ownership, serving the communities they come from, black, indigenous, and people of color.
There is an opportunity to continue building this capacity of organizations through the jump start funds.
That is going to come out later in this year.
For now, we wanted to highlight these three examples of the assistance that we have been providing these groups.

The two that we wanted to highlight, one is gate keeping.

This is persons who work in institutions that often function as gate keepers to ensure that institutions perpetuate itself with networking with those who share those values and maintaining accountability in the community.
The gate keeper becomes an Nugzal.
How do we show up in this space and make sure we are letting in, like, we are not being an inappropriate gate keeper?

If is not possible to live in the United States and not experience the impacts of colonial racism and other forms of oppression, advantage or disadvantage on our lives.
